original_title: Sri Lanka to intervene in transferring benefit of rupee appreciation to consumers
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka is looking at possible avenues of intervention for consumers to benefit from the ongoing appreciation of the rupee against the dollar, State Minister of Finance Ranjith Siyambalapitiya said.

Speaking to reporters on Friday May 19, Siyambalapitiya said the rupee has appreciated by about 18 to 20 percent, which must be reflected in the prices of imported goods and locally manufactured goods that are dependent on imported inputs.
“About 75 percent of the goods in the domestic market are either directly imported or import-dependent, so the public must feel its effects,” he said.

The state minister said the Finance Ministry’s Department of Trade and Investment Policies is currently researching ways in which the authorities can intervene in facilitating price reductions in construction material, food and other agricultural products, school equipment and the like.
“The dollar falling and the rupee rising means the benefit must definitely go to the people,” he said.
Sri Lanka’s bond yields were steady at open on Friday and the rupee opened at 307.20/308.00 against the US dollar in the spot market, dealers said.
A bond maturing on 01.09.2027 was quoted at 26.30/27.00 percent, unchanged from Wednesday’s close.
The rupee opened at 307.20/308.00 against the US dollar in the spot market weaker from yesterday’s close at 305.80/306.20. (Colombo/May19/2023)
